sourceDesc.p: Annotations for the Digital Anon project

person.note: Sir Francis Acton is an antagonist in one of the two intertwined subplots of Thomas Heywood's domestic tragedy A Woman Killed with Kindness. He is the brother of Anne Frankford (persistently referred to by Woolf as Frankland). He and Sir Charles Mountford brawl over the result of a hawking competition, and in the brawl Mountford kills Acton's two huntsmen. Mountford is released from prison but left impoverished by the fees: at the time Heywood was writing, English gaols charged their inmates for food, upkeep, and any privileges that an inmate could afford, and becomes significantly indebted and returns to prison as a debtor. Seeking further revenge against Mountford, Acton decides to seduce Mountford's sister, Susan. Acton wishes to use their affair to disgrace Mountford but falls in love with Susan. Hoping to win Susan's affection, Acton pays off Mountford's debts and drops charges for the murder of his huntsmen. In a gesture of thanks, Mountford offers his sister to Acton, whether to marry or 'To seize her as a rape or lustful prey [...] To murder her that never meant thee harm' (14.127-9). Susan reluctantly agrees to marry Acton when he professes his genuine love for her. See A Woman Killed With Kindness for more details.
Agrippa is a blooper
The hero of this story...
Could refer to a number of Archbishops...
The once and future king of England
Anne Bacon, mother of Francis Bacon
Francis Bacon, Viscount St Alban, Lord Chancellor of England
Francis Beaumont, playwright
Ludwig van Beethoven, composer
Thomas Betson, ???
Thomas Bilney, martyr
Shakespeare scholar of note
Physician and writer. Will need quite a long note here...
Will need a long note here less because of him, more because of Flush
Author of The Anatomy of Melancholy - CHECK THAT!!!

Cato most likely refers to one of two Roman senators, Cato the Elder (Marcus Porcius Cato; 234-149 BCE) or Cato the Younger (Marcus Porcius Cato Uticensis; 95-46 BCE). Both were conservative politicians and noted orators: Cato the Elder wrote De agri cultura, the oldest extant work of Latin prose, while Cato the Younger campaigned against Julius Caesar in the civil war that birthed the Roman Empire. Woolf references Joseph Addison's Cato, a Tragedy (1712) in her CR1 essay titled 'Addison' and O. Addison's play dramatises the final days of Caesar's civil war and of Cato the Younger's life. The Woolfs had multiple (CHECK) copies of this play in their library: one in a standalone edition from 1750, the others in collected editions.
William Caxton, printer
We're gonna need a bigger note.
Chicago suburb
Character from 'A Legacy'.
Character from 'A Legacy'.
Queen of Egypt
Countess of Dorset, Pembroke, and Montgomery. Woolfs had Diary in library, introduced by VSW and w/ LW's annotations!
Baron Cobham, patron of Harrison - dedicated Description of England to him
Samuel Taylor Coleridge, poet. Woolfs must have had about a trillion copies of him (20), gonna be a big ol' note.
Part of trio of 'invisible influences'...
Thomas Dekker, playwright. Two editions, one part of a series titled 'The Best Plays of the Old Dramatists' and the other a 1924 Bodley Head reprint of his 1603 play 'The VVonderfull Yeare'.
First Earl of Denbigh. Can't remember why Woolf brings him up... Interesting life though
Edward IV, King of England
Edward VI, King of England
Elizabeth I, Queen of England
A Mystery - do some digging. She marries Lord Sheffield, right?
Character in Shakespeare's Henry IV plays (check this...!)

John Ford, playwright. Known today for his 1631 tragedy 'Tis Pity She's a Whore. The Woolfs owned an edition of his plays, edited by Havelock Ellis and published as part of a series titled 'The Best Plays of the Old Dramatists.'

Master John Frankford (persistently referred to by Woolf as Frankland) is a major character in Thomas Heywood's domestic tragedy A Woman Killed With Kindness. The play opens with his marriage to Anne Frankford, the sister of Sir Francis Acton, and his decision to invite Wendoll to stay in his household as a long-term, perhaps permanent, guest. Anne Frankford and Wendoll begin an affair, which Frankland later discovers, walking in on Anne and Wendoll in bed. He is restrained from killing Wendoll and exiles Anne, saying that he intends to 'not martyr thee | Nor mark thee for a strumpet, but with usage | Of more humility torment thy soul | And kill thee, even with kindness' (13.150-1). Seeking to repent, Anne starves herself. Hearing of her parlous health, Frankford rushes to Anne's sickbed and the two reconcile, but this is not enough to prevent her death.

Anne Frankford (consistently referred to by Woolf as Frankland) is a major character in one of the two subplots of Thomas Heywood's domestic tragedy A Woman Killed With Kindness. She is the sister of Sir Francis Acton. The play opens with her marriage to Master John Frankland. John Frankland invites Wendoll to live in the newlyweds' home as a permanent guest, and Anne and Wendoll begin an affair. Frankford discovers the pair, and is restrained from killing Wendoll. In an act of retribution intended to 'torment [her] soul' and 'kill [her], even with kindness' (13.150-1), John exiles Anne and all of her possessions to a manor some seven miles from their home, and directs her to live out the rest of her days there. Her days are cut short as Anne starves herself, seeking to repent. Frankford is summoned to Anne's side, which gives the pair the chance to reconcile, but this is not enough to prevent Anne's death.
Reputedly killed Marlowe (find source for quotes)
Possible Dark Lady of Shakespeare's sonnets
Came from Gawsworth in Cheshire, Member of Parliament for Wigan, father of Mary Fytton (expand)
Wawan
John Gower, poet. Nowt in Woolfs lib by him but maybe in RN, E?
Walter Wilson Greg, Shakespeare scholar. Check RN for work by him.
Possibly Elizabeth Grey, Countess of Kent. Collected medical recipes which saw publication after her death.
William Harrison, author of A Description of England (CHECK)
Henry VIII, King of England. Too many wives.
Philip Henslowe, theatre owner and manager. Look at RN for diaries
Possibly Mary Herbert (nee Sidney), Countess of Pembroke of Countess of Pembroke's Arcadia fame http://viaf.org/viaf/32005754 or her granddaughter, Mary Herbert... Do some digging
Thomas Heywood, playwright. Author of A Woman Killed with Kindness.
Thomas Hobbes, philosopher. Woolfs had two copies of his Leviathan and one of his Behemoth, or The Long Parliament in their library.
Raphael Holinshed, chronicler. Author of whatever
Robin Hood, quasi-mythical outlaw who lived in Sherwood Forest, Nottingham.
Henrik Ibsen, playwright. Woolfs had a copy of his The Master Builder and of his 12-volume Collected Works in their library.

person.persName: James I of England and VI of Scotland
person.note: James I, King of England and Scotland. Author of Daemonologie (1597), Woolfs had reprint of this in library - check!.
Henry James, novelist. Woolfs had 24 works by him in their library.
Character in Blackadder. Gonna be a chonky note when I get round to it. Also ought to talk about Boswell - Woolf *bound* his Journey to the Hebrides and had three versions of his Life of SJ
Three volume Mermaids edition of plays in library, plus two edition of Timbers, which is the one she discusses here (and not any of the plays...)
Shakespearean actor type.
Sir William Knollys, 1st Earl of Banbury. Why does Woolf mention 'im? Oh, he has a very weird relationship with Mary Fytton. Scour for more info.
Thomas Kyd, playwright. Woolfs had an 1898 copy of his Spanish Tragedy in their library.
Character in Between the Acts
One of the knights of the round table. Their songs are formid-able, though many times they're given rhymes that are quite unsing-able.
John Leland, very influential antiquary and English historian. No idea what Woolf does with him.
Which one?
Poet who wrote exceptionally long poems...
Author of Le Morte d'Arthur, of which Woolfs had two copies in their library.
Sixth Earl of Rutland, probably. Employed Shakespeare and Richard Burbage to paint his emblem.
Christopher Marlowe, playwright. Big note here –– 2 copies of Works of CM in library (including an 'unexpurgated' one ed. Havelock Ellis), and one of Hero and Leander.
Playwright who fueded with Ben Jonson.
Collaborated with Martin Luther, first systematic theologian of Protestant Reformation, whatever that means.
Wizard.
Michelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simono, but famous enough to go by one name (like Beyonce). In the room the women come and go / Talking of Michelangelo
One of the weirdest playwrights of the 16th and 17th centuries.
Character in Woolf's short story 'A Legacy' -- notes for this in m48?
Michel Eyquem de Montaigne, essayist. Continual touchstone for VW. Woolfs had five copies of his Essays in both English and French in their library, and his diaries which were published by HP.
Arthurian sorceress.
Maurice Morgann, Shakespeare scholar. Woolfs had an 1892 edition of Morgann's Essay on the Dramatic Character of Sir John Falstaff in their library.

Author, socialist, creator of jazzy patterns. The Woolfs had three (3) copies of his 1903 poetry collection The Defence of Guenevere and Other Poems in their library, one a gift from Lytton Strachey to LW and another a gift from Philip Sidney Woolf and Cecil Woolf to LW, and a copy of his 1915 The Pilgrims of Hope and Chants for Socialists.
Renaissance Weird Little Guy. Woolf discusses The Unfortunate Traveller.
CHECK - might be a weird hapax legomenon who only appears in Anne Clifford's diary
Nin, Crot and Pully
Lady Elizabeth Stafford, later Elizabeth Howard, Duchess of Norfolk, which is how Woolf refers to her. here. Patron of John Skelton. Mother of Henry Howard, Earl of Surrey.
Character from BA. Paterfamilias. Grumpy old man.
Character from BA. Not-so closeted fascist.
Character from BA. Frustrated poet, probably deserves better than Giles.
William Herbert, 3rd Earl of Pembroke. Dedicatee of First Folio, possible Mr. W. H., bloke outside the Bod.
Samuel Pepys, diarist, EM horndog. Woolfs had four editions of his diary in their library.

person.persName: Pliny the Elder or Pliny the Younger
person.note: Try to find out? Does she mention either anywhere else?
Pully, Nin and Crot
Religious extremists, pretty much. Won the Civil War, shut down the theatres in 1642.
Favourite of Queen Elizabeth, discovered potatoes, despite contribution to British cuisine this did not save him from the axe.
Rafaello Sanzino da Urbino. Ninja Turtle
What does Woolf say about her?
Check in Diaries of Lady Anne Clifford

Better known in English as Madame de Sevigné. French aristocrat, and prolific letter-writer. Didn't VW write an essay on her? Woolfs had 3 French-language editions of her letters in their library, as well as two copies of Edward FitzGerald's 1914 Dictionary of Madame de Sevigné: one of these has a handwritten index in VW's hand.
William Shakespeare, playwright. Woolfs had 39 separate editions of works by Shakespeare in their library - definitely worth digging. Perhaps a project to make case for Woolf Digital Library???.
Edmund Sheffield, 2nd Earl of Mulgrave, I think...

Sir Philip Sidney, a poet, soldier and courtier to Queen Elizabeth. Woolfs had one volume of a two-volume, 1873 edition of his complete poems, as well as two editions of The Countess of Pembroke's Arcadia, a tenth edition dating to 1655 and an eleventh dating from 1662. She must have written about him elsewhere, right?
Robert Sidney, First Earl of Leicester, was the younger brother of Sir Philip Sidney. Patron of arts, Ben Jonson wrote about Penshurst (LOOK UP!).
CHECK - steamed hams steamed hams steamed hams

Bartholomew Oliver’s Afghan Hound named Sohrab. The locus classicus for the name Sohrab is Matthew Arnold’s 1853 quasi-Miltonic epic poem ‘Sohrab and Rustum.’ Woolf knew this poem: her library contain’s Arnold’s 1859 Poems, which prints ‘Sohrab and Rustum,’ while she reports in a diary entry of 9th May 1897 that Leslie Stephen recited the poem ‘after dinner’ (PA 83). Arnold’s poem relates how Rustum, an Iranian warrior, killed Sohrab, a warrior in the Tatar host and the son Rustum did not know he had, in single combat (Arnold 302-331). The name Sohrab is a double intertext: within Woolf’s own corpus it recalls Old Rustum in Orlando (cf. O 131), the gypsy who disabuses the newly female Orlando of her pride in what she had previously considered her illustrious heritage (O 136). As a further doggy aside, Orlando has a 'seluchi' (or saluki) in Turkey (O 129)—a type of sighthound related to the Afghan hound.

A small man with cuffs and a band. The Woolfs owned two editions of Spenser’s work, a five-volume 1862 edition edited by J. Payne Collier (which was presented to, and annotated by, Leslie Stephen) and a single-volume 1899 edition edited by R. Morris. It is likely that Woolf found this description in the 1862 edition, which contains a brief, unattributed biography of Spenser with this line. Look at essay on Faerie Qveene, etc.
Elizabethan actor best known for his death: he was killed in a duel with Ben Jonson. One of the strange Elizabethans in Woolf's CRI essay of that title.
Patron saint of England, dragon-slayer, etc. Can't for the life of me remember why he's here

Possibly Anne Stanley, Countess of Castlehaven. No idea why she's here - supporter of Spenser, Dnne, Milton perhaps, husband investigated by Privy Council on charges including rape and sodomy, then executed.
Stationers' Office. Acted as the government censor for however long.
Gaius Suetonius Tranquillus, Roman historian. Woolfs had a 1893 Latin edition of his surviving works titled C. Suetoni Tranquili quae supersunt omnia in their library.
Henry Howard, who had the dubious honour of being the last person executed on the orders of Henry VIII.
Character in Between the Acts. Old Flimsy.
Alfred, Lord Tennyson, Poet Laureate who loved vooooooweeeeelllll sounds. Woolfs had 13 volumes of his poetry in their library.

Playwright and poet best known for The Atheist's Tragedy. He was previously known for Revengers' Tragedy (does Woolf write about this) but this has since been attributed to Middleton. Woolf had one volume of a two-volume edition of his plays and poems in their library

G.M. Trevelyan was an eminent historian associated with Trinity College, Cambridge. Was he there same time as LW?. In addition to histories of England and Britain, wrote a trilogy of works on Garibaldi. Seven works in library.
Unknown.
Mr. W.H., the unknown dedicatee of Shakespeare's Sonnets.

A character in A Woman Killed with Kindness, the domestic tragedy by Thomas Heywood. Wendoll is invited by John Frankford to live with Frankford and his newlywed wife, Anne. Wendoll is smitten by Anne and seduces her. The two begin an affair, which is brought to an abrupt halt when Frankford devises a scheme to discover them. He is restrained from killing Wendoll, whom he exiles in disgrace instead. Wendoll and Anne have one final meeting in the final scenes of the play, as Anne starves herself in an act of contrition.
Rowland Whyte, courtier and diplomat. Postmaster at court of Queen Liz.

Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton. Dedicatee of Shax's Venus and Adonis and The Rape of Lucrece and has been identified as the Fair Youth of Shakespeare's sonnets (BY WHOMST)? Pronounced 'Risley'.
Bible Guy.

W.B. Yeats, poet. Woolfs had seven volumes of his works in their library, and HP published L. A. G. (Leonard Arthur George) Strong's A Letter to W. B. Yeats in 1932, as the sixth of their Hogarth Letter series.

Also, seven-vol. edition of FB's Life and Letters with LS's signature, annotations, drawing, 10-vol edition of Works with VW's binding, James Stephen Jr (who?) bookplates, LW's annotations. A family affair!

bibl.title: A Woman Killed with Kindness
bibl.author: Heywood, Thomas
bibl.note: A Woman Killed with Kindness, by Thomas Heywood, was first performed in 1603 though the earliest surviving text of the play dates from 1607. The play originates the genre of the domestic tragedy, and its two intertwining plots deal with lust and chastity, friendship and duty, retribution and pity. TBC.

object.note: A comma is a butterfly of the species Polygonia c-album. In A History of British Butterflies (1853 but reprinted well into the twentieth century), naturalist F.O. Morris notes that this ‘handsome and singularly shaped species’ appeared across Britain, but evidently it was rare enough (at least in the south-west London suburb of Surbiton) by the time Woolf wrote to justify being mentioned in the newspaper. With its wings closed, the butterfly looks like a fallen autumn leaf; its wings open to reveal a ‘beautiful rich fulvous orange colour.’ Cf. Morris (70-72). Francis Orpen Morris (1810-1893) was a popular British naturalist, cleric, and anti-Darwinist. In Jacob’s Room, the young Jacob Flanders corrects one of Morris’s works, probably the four-volume History of British Moths (1859-70), cf. JR 34
The mythical sword of King Arthur, lobbed at him by the Lady of the Lake
The Holy Grail, the cup used by Jesus at the Last Supper and sought by the Knights of the Round Table, and by Indiana Jones and some Nazis
Knights of the round table, our shows are formid-able etc.

place.note: Town in Wiltshire. Not sure why it's here but hey-ho.
Bankside, London. South of the river, where the Globe etc. were located.
Think this was a tavern or something.
Another tavern, probs. Or a theatre?
North Berwick, Northumberland. On the border of England and Scotland, apparently something to do with the pilliwinks.
Blackfriars, London. North of the river, where Copilot thinks the indoor theatres were located. Orlando's remaining property was located here.
Prison in Oxford from c.13th to 1771. Cramner and Latimer were imprisoned here before being burnt at stake. Look up something called Jackson's Oxford Journal...
Site of a hill fort in Somerset, England, according to Copilot, which seems to know a fair amount about small English towns. Thought to be Arthurian, which is probably the link.
Cambridge, Cambridgeshire.
Camelot, England. Arthurian. Where is this?
Canterbury, Kent. Where Thomas Becket got murdered and the Pilgrims tried to go.
Carlisle, Cumbria. Very northern, think Woolf discusses this with reference to Arthurian stuff.
Narrow channel of ocean connecting England and France. Rather choppy.
Cheshire, Cheshire. Where the Cheshire Cat comes from.
Something to do with the pilliwinks?
Old tavern, probs.
Old tavern, probs.
South-East London suburb, home to one Christopher Marlowe.
Major port on the South coast of England. White cliffs, Dover Castle and suchlike.
University with a small town attached to it. Too hilly for words.
County.
Fortune Theatre, London. Presumably not the current one, though.
Cheshire village. Gawsworth Hall is there, which is where the Cheshire Cat comes from.
Where Shakespeare's plays were performed. Bring good shoes.
The Bacons' house.
One of the four Inns of Court. The Woolfs lived here, didn't they?
Greenwich, London. Where the Prime Meridian is.
Elizabeth Talbot, Countess of Shrewsbury, aka Bess of Hardwick, lived here.
Kenilworth, Warwickshire. Where Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester, lived.
Knole, Kent. Where Vita Sackville-West and generations of Sackville-Westses lived. Can't remember why it came up here
Tributary of the Thames. Can't remember why it's of note here?
Capital of England and the United Kingdom. Big Smoke.
London Bridge, London. Where the nursery rhyme happened.
Historic region of Scotland centring on Edinburgh. Where the pilliwinks were?
Small island off the coast of Devon. Beloved of puffins.
Old tavern, probs.
County. Blo' Norton Hall, Joan Martyn story, Pastons
City. Where the Bocardo is.
Yeeeeeesh, how the hell do I note this. Guess historical Palestine not coterminous with current Palestine, centred around Jerusalem (?) and subject of Crusades? Where does this come up...
Home of Sir Philip Sidney.
Village and civil parish in Essex, and home to Harrison.
Capital of Italy. Not quite sure why this comes up here. Wasn't there a heavy leather curtain in a church in Rome somewhere in Woolf?
Old playhouse, I think.
District of London on the south bank of the Thames, where the Globe and other playhouses were situated.
City in Hertfordshire. Where Bacon was born and lived.
St Paul's Cathedral, London. Where the pilliwinks were?
Stonehenge, Wiltshire. Where the pilliwinks were?
Southern London suburb, surprisingly close to Hampton Court Park and Kingston. Funny, always thought it was further out.
Old playhouse, perhaps.
Where the Crown Jewels are kept. Also where Anne Boleyn was imprisoned and executed.
Head church of the Church of England, where monarchs crowned etc.
Historic county that's now part of Cumbria. Nae idea.
Where the civil servants hang out
Country house in Wiltshire, England. Where the Herberts lived.
City in Hampshire. Can't remember why Woolf brings this up
Maker of the best tea.
